docs.snippet: The case stems from the 2010 season, when there was no salary cap and, the players union claims, teams worked together to keep salaries artificially low....
docs.lead_paragraph: The case stems from the 2010 season, when there was no salary cap and, the players union claims, teams worked together to keep salaries artificially low.
docs.abstract: Federal appeals court reinstates case brought by the NFL Player's Association accusing NFL owners of collusion by creating a secret salary cap in the 2010 season; case had been dismissed by federal judge in 2012.

headline.main: N.F.L. Collusion Case Reinstated on Appeal

docs.snippet: Mexican fans taunted the opposing goalkeepers in their first two World Cup games with a cheer that ends by shouting a word widely regarded as a derogatory term used against gays....
docs.lead_paragraph: Mexican fans taunted the opposing goalkeepers in their first two World Cup games with a cheer that ends by shouting a word widely regarded as a derogatory term used against gays.
docs.abstract: FIFA opens disciplinary proceedings against Mexican national team for what it calls 'improper conduct of spectators' at the World Cup; Mexican fans taunted opposing goalkeepers during victory over Cameroon with traditional cheer that ends with anti-gay slur.

headline.main: FIFA Looking Into Possible Use of Gay Slur by Mexican Fans
headline.print_headline: Looking Into Possible Use of Gay Slur

byline.contributor: Reporting contributed by Paulina Villegas from Mexico City.

docs.snippet: Humberto Clavijo, who infuriated Mexico with two decisions in its victory over Cameroon, will not be part of the officiating team at the South Korea-Algeria match Sunday....
docs.lead_paragraph: Humberto Clavijo, who infuriated Mexico with two decisions in its victory over Cameroon, will not be part of the officiating team at the South Korea-Algeria match Sunday.
docs.abstract: World Cup Roundup; FIFA drops linesman Humberto Clavijo of Colombia from his crew's next assignment at the World Cup after he made offside decisions that denied Mexico two potential goals in team’s opening game against Cameroon; other soccer news noted.

headline.main: Linesman Is Replaced After Two Curious Offside Calls

docs.snippet: After being unresponsive from a knee to the head, Álvaro Pereira insisted on playing through Uruguay’s game with England, and was allowed to continue, a decision that drew criticism....
docs.lead_paragraph: After being unresponsive from a knee to the head, Álvaro Pereira insisted on playing through Uruguay’s game with England, and was allowed to continue, a decision that drew criticism.
docs.abstract: Decision to allow injured Uruguayan midfielder Alvaro Periera to continue playing in World Cup group match against England draws criticism; Periera insisted on playing after taking knee to head, despite fact that he was temporarily unresponsive following impact; decision plunges sport into new discussions about how to handle head injuries at time when concussions are becoming major concern in other sports.

headline.seo: Uruguayan Player’s Return After Head Injury Stirs Debate
headline.main: ‘Lights Went Out,’ but He Kept Playing
headline.print_headline: Pereira’s Play Stirs Debate Over Injuries

docs.snippet: Not a single player at this World Cup has tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug, a sign that FIFA is closing its eyes and pretending that doping in soccer does not exist....
docs.lead_paragraph: Not a single player at this World Cup has tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug, a sign that FIFA is closing its eyes and pretending that doping in soccer does not exist.
docs.abstract: Juliet Macur Sports Of The Times Column mocks FIFA's claim that not a single player at the World Cup has tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs, arguing that such a 'perfect record' is deeply suspicious; contends that governing body has closed its eyes to the issue, much as it has with other endemic soccer problems like match fixing, racism and head injuries.

headline.main: No Doping at the World Cup? That’s What FIFA Says
headline.print_headline: No Doping at the World Cup? That’s What FIFA Says

docs.snippet: Switzerland central defender Steve von Bergen is out of the World Cup after breaking a facial bone in his team's 5-2 loss to France....
docs.lead_paragraph: Switzerland central defender Steve von Bergen is out of the World Cup after breaking a facial bone in his team's 5-2 loss to France.

headline.main: Switzerland Defender Von Bergen Out of World Cup
headline.print_headline: Switzerland Defender Von Bergen Out of World Cup

docs.snippet: Macau police have busted a bookmaking racket that allegedly took HK$5 billion (379 million pounds) in illegal bets - including a single HK$40 million bet - on World Cup football matches in a week, the South China Morning Post reported on Saturday....
docs.lead_paragraph: Macau police have busted a bookmaking racket that allegedly took HK$5 billion (379 million pounds) in illegal bets - including a single HK$40 million bet - on World Cup football matches in a week, the South China Morning Post reported on Saturday.

headline.main: Police Smash Major World Cup Betting Ring in Macau
headline.print_headline: Police Smash Major World Cup Betting Ring in Macau

docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil's Dani Alves hit out at former England striker Alan Shearer on Saturday, saying his comments about centre-forward Fred were some of the stupidest he had ever heard.

headline.main: Shearer's Comments on Fred 'Idiotic', Says Dani Alves
